definition: Penal code for murder in California; to kill someone
context: They tagged 187 on the wall after the hit. That dude tried to 187 me last night.
5-0 coming down the block, let's bounce. Watch out for 5-0 around the corner.
He's a real banger from the east side. Those bangers are deep in that neighborhood.
We got beef with them cats from uptown. Don't start no beef you can't finish.
They tried to blast him at the corner store. I heard shots, somebody got blasted.

definition: To gain admission to some gangs you must kill someone, and to resign you must die or you will be killed by fellow members
context: This set is blood-in, blood-out, no walking away. You knew it was blood-in, blood-out when you signed up.
He threatened to bust a cap in anybody who snitched. They busted a cap at the rival crew.
That dude's a buster, he ain't really about it. Don't trust him, he's just a buster trying to fit in.
Come through to my crib later. We laying low at his crib tonight.
I'm just trying to stack dead presidents. He's all about them dead presidents.
He keeps a deuce deuce in his waistband. That's just a deuce deuce, nothing major.
I just need a dime bag real quick. He's out here selling dime bags on the corner.
Word is he's dropping dimes to the cops. Nobody likes a rat who's dropping dimes.
He's thinking about dropping the flag and going straight. They don't let you just drop the flag like that.
I need to re-up on an eight ball. He moved an eight ball in one night.
Pass that ganja this way. We sitting back smoking ganja all day.
Somebody ganked my phone at the party. He tried to gank money from the register.

definition: Law enforcement officer; Gun; Unwanted attention
context: The heat is watching the spot. I'm packing heat tonight. This plan is bringing too much heat.

definition: Drug dealer; usually shot-callers who control the drug trafficking of a gang and retain the bulk of the drug profits
context: He's a high roller moving weight across the city. The high rollers don't touch the product themselves.

definition: One of the boys from the neighborhood gang or group; a fellow gang member
context: That's my homeboy from way back. All my homeboys got my back.
That's a hot box, ditch it before the cops see. We riding in a hot box tonight.

definition: One who makes money by any means necessary
context: He's a real hustler, always got something going. These streets are full of hustlers trying to get by.
He got jacked for his chain last night. They jacked the store on Fifth Street.

definition: A prison; the walls; a marijuana cigarette
context: He just got out the joint after five years. Pass that joint. My boy doing time in the joint.
He got jumped in last week, took a beating. They jumped him in behind the school.

definition: A letter or note to another inmate, usually slid under the door (from cell to cell) by means of a thin string
context: Send me a kite when you get to C block. I got a kite from my cellie down the tier.
Let's ride on them fools tonight. They talking about riding on the east side crew.
He's tweaking on that liquid juice. Don't mess with liquid juice, that stuff is dangerous.
What's up loc? That dude is straight loc, no fear.
We going on a mission tonight. He just got back from a mission, better lay low.
They came through mobbing deep. We was mobbing through their territory.

definition: One who smuggles drugs or other contraband into the prison for another inmate
context: His girl is the mule bringing stuff in on visits. They caught the mule at the gate.
I keep my nine on me at all times. He pulled out his nine when they rushed him.

definition: Someone to be seriously beaten or murdered
context: That snitch is on the menu tonight. You keep talking, you'll be on the menu.

definition: Person has a gun in his possession
context: You know I'm always packing. He was packing when they searched him.
Make sure you bring your piece. He pulled out his piece during the argument.

definition: Street on which the Bloods originated; Nickname for the Bloods
context: He's Piru through and through. The Pirus run that neighborhood.
My cousin got popped last night. They popped him for possession.

definition: Do a shooting; performing gang duties
context: He's been putting in work for the set. You gotta put in work to earn respect.

definition: To seek someone out as a target of some violent act
context: We about to ride on them tonight. They rode on us last week, now it's our turn.
He's smoking rock all day. Got any rock for sale?

definition: Gang neighborhood; a member refers to his gang as a set of a larger nation of gangs
context: What set you claiming? I rep my set till I die.
He's on that sherm, acting crazy. Don't smoke sherm, that stuff will mess you up.
He's the shotcaller for this block. The shotcaller gives all the orders.
He's out here slanging to make rent. They been slanging on that corner for years.

definition: Disrespectful way of addressing a Bloods member
context: Crips call Bloods 'slobs' as disrespect. They threw up signs dissing the slobs.

definition: An informer; fink; rat; stool pigeon
context: He's a snitch working with the cops. Snitches get stitches around here.
He OD'd on a speed ball. Speed balls are deadly, man.

definition: Display of hand signals, communication between gang members
context: They was stacking when I walked by. He threw up his set, stacking to let them know.
Stay strapped or get clapped. We all strapped tonight, just in case.
Let's throw down right now. They threw down in the parking lot.
Keep that tool on you. He reached for his tool when they approached.

definition: To break a gang rule and receive a punishment
context: That's a violation, he gonna get checked. He caught a violation for talking to the cops.
They wacked him last Tuesday. Word is the snitch got wacked.

definition: Are you a member of a gang?
context: He rolled up asking 'where you from?' When someone asks where you from, they checking if you gang affiliated.
He moving that yayo cross town. Got some good yayo if you need it.
Get on the ameche and call him. The ameche's been ringing all morning.
He pulled out his bean-shooter. Better bring your bean-shooter to this job.
He did ten years in the big house. They sent him to the big house for armed robbery.

definition: Little folded-up piece of paper of heroin; The bundle in which a hobo carries all his worldly possessions
context: He bought a bindle on the corner. The hobo carried his bindle over his shoulder.
The boss wants us to blow that guy down. They blew down three cops in the shootout.
Get in the boiler, we gotta scram. His boiler's parked around the corner.
The contract is to bop the DA. They bopped him last night in the alley.
The cops slapped the bracelets on him. He was wearing bracelets when they dragged him out.
The bulls are tailing us. Watch out for bulls in the area.
The boss ordered a bump on the informant. They bumped him off quietly.
Things got hot and we had to burn powder. They burned powder all night in that shootout.

definition: The money man, the man with the bankroll, a yokel who comes to town to blow a big wad in nightclubs
context: Here comes the butter and egg man ready to spend. We need a butter and egg man to finance this operation.
How much cabbage you got on you? This job will bring in serious cabbage.
He spent the night in the caboose. They're gonna throw you in the caboose.
He's been in the can for two months. Better watch out or you'll end up in the can.
Keep talking and you'll end up in a Chicago overcoat. They fitted him for a Chicago overcoat.
The witness got chilled off before trial. He was chilled off in his own apartment.
He tried to chisel me on the deal. Don't let him chisel you out of your cut.

definition: Knife, or other stabbing or cutting weapon
context: He pulled a chiv during the fight. Better carry a chiv for protection.
Send in the chopper squad. The chopper squad took care of the competition.

definition: A night-club where the prices are high and the patrons are fleeced; A casino where the tables are fixed
context: That place is a clip joint, don't go there. We ran a clip joint downtown for years.
They threw him in the cooler overnight. He's cooling off in the cooler.
The coppers are on our tail. Don't trust that copper, he's crooked.
The mob wants to croak him. He got croaked in a drive-by.
Get the croaker, he's been shot. We need a croaker who doesn't ask questions.
Three cons crushed out last night. He crushed out through the laundry room.

definition: Detective (usually qualified with 'private' if not a policeman)
context: Some dick has been following me. I hired a private dick to tail my wife.
There's a dip working the subway. He's the best dip in the city.
He's dealing dope on the corner. Give me the dope on the new guy. What's the dope on this job?
He's turned into a dope fiend. Don't trust a dope fiend with your money.
How much dough we talking? I need to make some dough fast.
They drilled him full of holes. I'm gonna drill anyone who crosses me.
The boss sent his best droppers. We need some droppers for this job.
Meet me at the drum on Fifth. We're hiding out in a drum uptown.

definition: Knock out, hit on head after ambushing
context: They dry-gulched him in the alley. We'll dry-gulch him when he comes out.
Lend me a fin until Friday. It'll cost you a fin to get in.
He fingered the guy who robbed him. Don't finger me or you're dead.
We took the getaway in an old flivver. His flivver broke down on the highway.
I'll fog anyone who gets in my way. They fogged the place up good.
Keep your gat handy. He pulled out his gat when the shooting started.
We need more geetus for this operation. Hand over the geetus.
Pour me some of that giggle juice. We got plenty of giggle juice for the party.
He owns three gin mills in Brooklyn. Let's hit the gin mill for a drink.
Somebody glaumed my wallet. He glaumed the diamonds from the safe.
That gonif stole my watch. He's a two-bit gonif, nothing more.
Send some goons to shake him down. His goons will rough you up.
He's all gowed-up on opium. They were gowed-up during the heist.
The job pays five grand. I lost two grand at the track.
He's a grifter running cons downtown. Don't trust that grifter.
Some gum-shoe has been asking questions. He's doing gum-shoe work for the DA.
Grab a hack and meet me there. We took a hack to the hideout.
Let's grab a bite at the hash house. He works at a hash house on Broadway.
The boss sent his hatchetmen. Watch out for the Chinese hatchetmen.
Better pack a heater on this job. He's carrying a heater in his coat.

definition: Liquor; An alcoholic beverage made by fermenting a sugary syrup or liquid and bread
context: Pass me that hooch. They're brewing hooch in the cell.
He's been in the hoosegow twice this year. They'll throw you in the hoosegow.

definition: Drugs, mostly morphine or derivatives like heroin
context: He's addicted to hop. You can get hop from the Chinese quarter.
He's nothing but a hop-head now. Don't deal with hop-heads, they're unreliable.
Get on the horn and call him. The horn's been ringing off the hook.
She's wearing some serious ice. We lifted the ice from the jewelry store.
He's been in stir for five years. My brother's in stir upstate.
Nice iron you got there. We need fresh iron for the job.
Pour me a cup of java. Let's grab some java at the diner.
You owe me the juice on that loan. The juice is 10% per week.

definition: Suitcase; also means buttocks or safe/strongbox
context: Grab the keister and let's go. They cracked the keister in ten minutes.
The boss wants us to knock him off. They knocked off three guards during the heist.
He lammed off before the cops arrived. They lammed off to Mexico.
Watch out, he's a loogan. The boss sent three loogans to handle it.
How much mazuma you need? This job will bring in plenty of mazuma.
Call the meat wagon, he's bleeding out. The meat wagon took three bodies away.

definition: Take off, leave; A drink drugged with knock-out drops
context: Let's take a mickey finn out of here. They slipped him a mickey finn at the bar.
He brought his moll to the meeting. That's the boss's moll, don't look at her.
Get me my mouthpiece. His mouthpiece got him off on a technicality.
They put the nippers on him. He slipped out of the nippers somehow.
He's been snorting nose-candy all night. You got any nose-candy?
He's a private op working the case. Some op has been tailing me.
There's a peeper asking questions about you. Hire a peeper to find out who did it.
He's doing ten years in the pen. They sent him to the state pen.
We need a good peterman for this job. The peterman blew the safe clean off.
He caught a pill in the chest. Pass me a pill, will ya?
He took a pinch last night. They made the pinch at dawn.
They started pumping metal everywhere. Time to pump some metal.
These bills are queer. He's passing queer money downtown.
He's beating the murder rap. What's the rap on this guy? I took the rap for him.
He ratted to the cops. Don't rat or you're dead.
We're hopping the rattler to Chicago. They robbed the rattler last night.
He's smoking reefers in the back. Got any reefers on you?
I need some rhino fast. This job will bring in plenty of rhino.
Keep your rod ready. He pulled his rod on me.
Better bring your roscoe. He's packing a roscoe under his coat.
It's gonna be a rub-out. The newspapers called it a gangland rub-out.
What a sap, he fell for it. He got sapped from behind.
Lend me a sawbuck. It'll cost you a sawbuck to get in.
You got any scratch on you? We need to raise some scratch.
He's the best scratcher in town. We need a scratcher for these documents.
Let's screw before the cops come. The screw is making his rounds.
Some shamus has been following me. Hire a shamus to tail him.
He pulled a shiv on me. Better carry a shiv for protection.
I owe the shylock ten grand. Don't borrow from a shylock, the juice will kill you.
There's a sleuth nosing around. The sleuth tracked them down.
He took three slugs to the chest. They slugged the guard and took his keys.
They snatched the kid for ransom. It's a snatch job, pay up or else.
He's turned into a snow-bird. Don't trust a snow-bird with anything.

definition: To crack a safe using nitroglycerine
context: It's gonna be a soup job. They did a soup job on the bank vault.
They started squirting metal at us. Time to squirt some metal.
He's gonna step off at dawn. They made him step off for the murders.
There's a stiff in the alley. They found three stiffs in the warehouse.
He's a stool-pigeon for the cops. Watch out for stool-pigeons.
Let's take a powder before trouble starts. He took a powder when the shooting began.
They're smoking tea in the back room. Got any tea on you?
They started throwing lead at us. Time to throw some lead.
The boss sent his torpedoes. Watch out for torpedoes in the area.

definition: Guy who does the shooting on a job
context: He's the trigger man for the mob. We need a good trigger man for this hit.
The vig is killing me. Pay the vig or they'll break your legs.
Make sure you wear iron on this job. He's wearing iron under his coat.
Keep talking and you'll end up in a wooden kimono. They put him in a wooden kimono.

definition: Safecracker, who can only open a rather cheap and vulnerable safe
context: We need a yegg for this job. He's just a yegg, can't crack the good ones.
He got zotzed last night. They zotzed the witness before trial.
He's straight from yard. This costs three yard.
The beasts gave him a bite last night. Watch out or you'll catch a bite.
Load up the teeth. He caught some teeth in the shootout.
The beasts are coming, scatter. Watch out for the beasts.

definition: It's okay, its first class, or that is excellent
context: Everything iric, man. That plan is iric.
Keep the yeung ready. He pulled out his yeung.
Pass me the gong. He's carrying a gong under his shirt.
Bring the shooty. He fired the shooty at them.
They came with the machine. Get the machine from the trunk.
Make sure we got enough rings. They brought plenty of rings to the fight.
Pass the ily. We smoking ily all night.
Roll up some corn. Got any corn on you?
We need some food. He's selling good food.
Fire! Fire! Let's go. When you hear fire, run.
Chase those baldheads out of town. We don't deal with baldheads.

definition: The world outside of the Rasta's world, the power structure, the police
context: Babylon is oppressing us. Fight against Babylon.
You bloodclot! That bloodclot tried to cross me.
Bumbaclot! Get out of here you bumbaclot.
You pussyclot! That pussyclot owes me money.
You ole rass you. Move your rass.

definition: Braids most Rastas wear, sometimes concealed under a hat
context: His dreadlocks are long. She wears her dreadlocks under a tam.
Praise Jah. Jah will protect us.

definition: Joint; one ounce of ganja makes approximately four spliffs
context: Roll up a spliff. Pass the spliff, man.
He's the don of the posse. The don makes all the decisions.

definition: High ranking member of the posse
context: He's a rankin in the organization. Only rankins can make that call.
He's a drug baron moving tons. The drug barons control everything.
They found him johted in the alley. He got johted for snitching.
The higglers bring stuff from yard. She's a higgler at the market.
He's a known druggler. The drugglers run the block.

definition: A person who has excessive desire
context: That licksy licksy policeman is on the take. He's a licksy licksy thief.
They don't trust mama man. He's a mama man.
He's a beemer, stays high. Those beemers are desperate.
He's selling bottles on the corner. Got five bottles in his pocket.

definition: Crack stem attachment used when stem is broken or too short
context: Need a carburetor for this stem. The carburetor broke off.

definition: Crack smokers searching on the floor for crumbs of crack
context: He's on carpet patrol again. They on carpet patrol looking for crumbs.
He's smoking cocoa puffs. Cocoa puffs will mess you up bad.

definition: Looking for crack, trying to buy crack; high on crack
context: He's on a mission right now. When she's on a mission, don't bother her.

definition: Good hit of crack; users hears bells
context: That was a ringer. He got a ringer off that hit.
Pass me the stem. His stem is burned up.
Those thirst monsters will do anything for a hit. The thirst monsters are out tonight.

definition: 24 hours a day, 7 days a week
context: We open 24/7. He's hustling 24/7.

definition: Neighborhood; synonymous with gang most of the time
context: This is my barrio. Don't come into our barrio.
Ese! What's up ese? Yo ese, come here.
Hey vato! That vato is crazy. What's up vato?
That's my carnal. My carnal got my back.

definition: Rule, reign, We Control, We Are The Best
context: Mi barrio rifa! We rifa this neighborhood.

definition: Watch Out! Get With It! Look Out!
context: Trucha! The cops are coming. Trucha vato, someone's watching.
Simon ese. Simon, that's right.

definition: Okay, stop fooling around; Hey! Okay! Right On!
context: Orale vato! Orale, let's go.
Pass the mota. He's selling mota.
That's firme. He's a firme
